item.title: About
item.description: I am a Data Scientist at Zeta Global building recommendation engines for media publishing houses. These days I am learning how recommendation engines work, exploring techniques like matrix factorization, factorization machines, and others. I have started using Python and I am loving it! I am a graduate from IIT Kharagpur with a Masters in Mathematics and Computing. I have picked up much of my understanding of machine learning at @WalmartLabs where I worked as Sr.

item.title: My First Hugo Post
item.description: Hello world, I am trying to create a site using Hugo static site generator. This is a markdown page. Trying color syntaxing using pygmentize import numpy as np import pandas as pd import matplotlip.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns # Add comment here Using hugo syntax highlight # Loading required packages import numpy as np import pandas as pd import matplotlip.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns

item.title: Time series and forecasting using R
item.description: Time series forecasting is a skill that few people claim to know. Machine learning is cool. And there are a lot of people interested in becoming a machine learning expert. But forecasting is something that is a little domain specific. Retailers like Walmart, Target use forecasting systems and tools to replenish their products in the stores. An excellent forecast system helps in winning the other pipelines of the supply chain.

item.title: Types of data in recommender systems
item.description: There are two ways in which we can collect data for building recommender systems — explicit and implicit. In this post, we will talk about both types of data, their characteristics and the challenges with them. Explicit feedback datasets The dictionary meaning of explicit is to state clearly and in detail. Explicit feedback data as the name suggests is an exact number given by a user to a product. Some of the examples of explicit feedback are ratings of movies by users on Netflix, ratings of products by users on Amazon.

Title: Understanding HIVE for data science people date: 2016-06-22 04:43 comments: true slug: understanding_hive_data_science Category: Big Data Tags: hive, hadoop, big data, manish barnwal description: This post is meant for data science folks who want to use and understand HIVE Keywords: Hive, hadoop, big data, , manish barnwal I have been working as Statistical analyst for the last 1.5 years and fortunately I got to work on Hadoop on one of my initial projects.

Title: The Big Data Problem date: 2016-06-29 7:00 comments: true slug: big_data_problem Category: Big Data Tags: big data, hadoop, machine-learning, manish barnwal description: This post talks about the big data problem and why we need it Keywords: big data, analytics, hadoop, spark, manish barnwal Big data has become a sensation these days. Anyone and everyone wants to use this in their discussions. When I was still in my college and preparing for campus placements, I had attended almost all the pre-placement talks that companies gave to its prospective candidates.

Title: When R package is not available across the cluster date: 2016-08-02 7:00 comments: true slug: r_packages_not_in_cluster Category: ML, Data Science Tags: R, hacks, manish barnwal description: This post talks about a hack which is useful if a particular R package is unavailable across the cluster Keywords: big data, R, manish barnwal When deploying R codes across the cluster, many a times the reason for the failure of the task is unavailability of a particular package across all nodes of the cluster.

Title: Hadoop Streaming date: 2016-08-29 7:00 comments: true slug: hadoop_streaming Category: Big Data Tags: big data, hive, tutorial, hadoop, manish barnwal description: This post talks about the hadoop streaming framework Keywords: big data, analytics, hadoop, manish barnwal A few days ago, I had written a post on The Big Data Problem{:target=”_blank”} which attempted to understand why we need big data and what the fuss is all about. You may want to read it here{:target=”_blank”}.

Title: ROC and AUC - The three lettered acronyms date: 2016-09-26 8:00 comments: true slug: three_letter_acronym_roc_and_auc Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks about roc curve and confusion matrix. Keywords: roc, auc, tpr, fpr, probability cut-off, manish barnwal I don’t feel bad to confess this that ROC curve, AUC, True-positive and related terms took quite some time for me to understand. If today I contemplate on the reasons why I found this topic confusing.

Title: Shell commands come in handy for a data scientist date: 2016-09-30 7:00 comments: true slug: shell_commands_for_data_scientist Category: ML, Data Science Tags: tutorial, hacks, machine-learning, manish barnwal description: This post talks about shell commands that come in handy for data-science people Keywords: shell-commands, manish barnwal I am no expert of shell commands. I have been using them for quite some time and thought I give an attempt to list down the most common commands.

Title: How to install a package of a particular version in R date: 2016-10-05 7:00 comments: true slug: install_a_package_particular_version_in_R Category: ML, Data Science Tags: R, hacks, manish barnwal description: This post explains how to install a package of a particular version in R Keywords: R, package, package version, manish barnwal I recently tried installing caret package in R using install.packages(‘caret’, dependencies=T) Normally this installation of package works and I continue to work with the functions associated with the package.

Title: Improve runtime of Random Forest in R date: 2016-10-13 10:00 comments: true slug: improve_runtime_random_forest_r Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, hacks, manish barnwal description: This post talks about a trick to improve the runtime of random forest package in R for large datasets Keywords: random forest, hack, manish barnwal There are two ways one can write the code to train a random forest model in R. Both the ways are listed below.

Title: Random Forest explained intuitively date: 2016-10-18 8:00 comments: true slug: random_forest_explained_intuitively Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post explains random forest intuitively Keywords: random forest, random forest tutorial, data-science, manish barnwal Random Forests algorithm has always fascinated me. I like how this algorithm can be easily explained to anyone without much hassle. One quick example, I use very frequently to explain the working of random forests is the way a company has multiple rounds of interview to hire a candidate.

Title: Visualization in ML is under-rated date: 2017-01-27 8:00 comments: true slug: visualization_is_under-rated Category: ML, Data Science Tags: visualization, machine-learning, manish barnwal description: This post talks about visualization -one of the most important aspects of data science that often gets ignored. Keywords: visualization, R, data science, ML, manish barnwal Visualization is one of the most important pillars of data science. Every one wants to learn Machine learning but if you explain them the little tasks that involve the overall workflow of the process, it turns them off.

Title: The curse of bias and variance [draft] date: 2017-02-08 8:00 comments: true slug: the_curse_of_bias_and_variance Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks about the trade-off between bias and variance. Keywords: ML, data science, overfitting, bias, variance, manish barnwal Statistics is the field of study where we try to draw conclusions about the population from a sample. Why do we talk about sample? Why can’t we get the conclusions about the population directly from the population?

Title: An illustrated introduction to adversarial validation part 1 date: 2017-02-15 8:00 comments: true slug: introduction_to_adversarial_validation Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks about adversarial validation- an approach to the problem of differently distributed training and test data. Keywords: ML, data science, cross-validation, adversarial-validation, manish barnwal You’d have heard about cross-validation - a common technique used in data-science process to avoid overfitting and many a times to tune the optimal parameters.

Title: How to use Git and Github date: 2017-02-15 10:00 comments: true slug: git_and_github Category: ML, Data Science Tags: tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks about the usage of git and github Keywords: git, github, manish barnwal I had taken this course - How to use git and github some time last year. This post is an amalgamation of the course notes and other tutorials I have completed in understanding git.

Title: An illustrated introduction to adversarial validation part 2 date: 2017-02-16 8:00 comments: true slug: introduction_to_adversarial_validation Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks about adversarial validation- an approach to the problem of differently distributed training and test data. Keywords: ML, data science, cross-validation, adversarial-validation, manish barnwal In the last post we talked about the idea of adversarial validation{:target=”_blank”} and how it helps the problem when your validation set result doesn’t comply with that of test set result.

Title: The essence of machine learning is function estimation date: 2017-05-12 8:00 comments: true slug: machine_learning_function_estimation Category: ML, Data Science Tags: machine-learning, tutorial, manish barnwal description: This post talks explains how the essence of machine learning is function estimation. The aim was to give a brief overview of machine learning.

Dockers help in software development in isolated frameworks.

Keywords: virtual environment, python, tutorial, manish barnwal I was trying to get a virtual environment set up on Python 3 using mkvirtualenv but somehow the virtual environment was getting created on Python 2.

Title: git and github for data scientists date: 2018-04-18 8:00 comments: true slug: git_and_github_for_data_scientists Category: ML, Data Science Tags: python, tutorial, hacks, manish barnwal description: This is a tutorial on git and github for anyone who wants to use it. Before this I used to work at WalmartLabs where we always wanted to use a version control system like git but it never took off properly.

Title: Working with dates in Python date: 2018-06-18 8:00 comments: true slug: working_with_dates_in_python Category: ML, Data Science Tags: python, tutorial, hacks, manish barnwal description: This tutorial is on ways to deal with dates in Python. Date columns need some methods applied to them The reason is I don’t normally see date columns in the data I work with so I don’t remember the functions and methods that work on dates to get meaningful columns out of the date column in the data.

item.title: Vim/Vi editor shortcuts
item.description: Repetitive tasks should be done using as many shortcuts as possible. You are not doing anything new and hence not even an extra minute should be spent on doing the same. This post refers to the shortcuts that come in handy when working on the vi/vim editor. This is not an exhaustive list. These are the ones I use frequently. Feel free to comment down your favorite shortcuts. Navigation keys 0             Moves cursor to the start of the line $             Moves cursor to the end of the line w             Moves forward one word b             Moves backward one word
